Comments_List:
I learned a lot of general techniques that are commonly used in chemical biology classes, but they generally were isolated to adding fluorphores onto proteins.

However, I am definitely more familiar with the vocabulary of my field, and have the mental tools to design complex experiments now.
good survey of modern techniques used in chemical biology research
In this course, we were introduced many techniques and mechanisms that could be applied to develop novel methods for discovery in the field of Chemical Biology.
I learned about the field of Chemical Biology. I learned about the methods and techniques commonly employed, as well as some of their history and most notable examples.
Natural product synthesis, library generation, nonstandard amino acid incorporation, fluorescent tagging methods, bio-orthogonal reactions, and genome editing techniques.
I learned a lot about chemical biology methods and got up to speed with my chemical biology background
As I said before, the diversity of applications for the concepts we learned were broad, but were only ever framed in the context of fluorescent labeling or looking for drug-protein interactions.

strengths:  professor schepartz
weaknesses: not enough professor schepartz

It seemed like there may have been some disconnect between the two professors that made the course seem less organized. For example, one would be unsure if the other professor had gone through a certain topic.

Strengths: It was a great course! It was interesting and well-taught.

Weaknesses: The class was team-taught by two professors, and they didn't always seem to be on the same page about assignments, homework, and exams. I think a few hours of organization throughout the semester would have smoothed things over a bit more.

The research proposal was a great assignment; I really enjoyed writing it. I was a little daunting at first when choosing a topic, but it's essentially license to just delve into any research problem of your choice and be creative, which I thought was fun.

Strengths- All-star professors covering broadly applicable topics in great detail.

Weaknesses- Not the best planning of the team-taught lectures relative to one another. As much as I enjoyed my personal project, giving up almost 3 weeks of the semester to listen to students present is a bit arduous and boring. I would rather hear the professors cover more topics. 

Thus, shift presentations to be out of class, or limit the class size. Also, that was an unreasonable number of papers to read and even the most dedicated students quickly fell behind. You need to select ~ 1 paper a week which is amazing, and leave the rest as references. No one has time to read 10 papers a week, where 2 are Reviews.
I liked the powerpoint format and the outline of topics that would be on each exam. I think the problem sets were a bit tedious in some questions, and they could be revised
Yes, it is a useful course for anyone that plans to do biophysical or chemical biology research.
yes
Yes, I would. If a student has an interest in applying chemistry in a biological setting, this class is great.
Definitely, to anyone interested in Chemical Biology.
Yes I would highly recommend!

Yes, I think this course covers in great mechanistic detail a large swath of the field of chemical biology. This course has made me feel literate in the concepts/terms that my chemical biology and biochemistry colleagues are using.
Yes
Yes. It was a good way to get a solid chemical biology background
